Description: Head of a duck: perhaps the mallard or the pintail, which together with the neck forms a complete unit. It is without piercing or other means of suspension. The head is in barely translucent dark-blue glass with the eyes formed of blobs of unidentified, opaque composition. The long beak is of translucent turquoise-blue glass. Areas under the head and on the lower neck have been overlaid with opaque yellow glass.
Curator's comments: A charming trifle which at once recalls the elaborate earrings of Tutankhamun on which the central motive is a very similar glass duck's head. This example must have served a similar perhaps identical function. It is an object certainly of royal origin. Bibliography: P. Fox, 'Tutankhamen's Treasure' (London 1951), pl. 49A.
